text: Oh my god

It's so strange to think that like 
this is what I look like in a 3D form.

Before we get any further some important context: 
there's a life-size statue of me in a park. But

it's not just me, I'm one of 121 statues of 
real living scientists. Don't we look cool?

So now you may be wondering... why are 
there 121 statues of scientists in a park?

And how did they all get there? Well that, my 
friends, is a story that involves a big idea,

cutting edge technology and one thing 
that's wrong with statues as we know them.

Two years ago I found myself in 
a room, in the back of a museum,

going through the motions of becoming 
a statue. This all came about because

i'm an if/then ambassador. I'm one of more 
than 120 women from all different science,

tech, engineering and maths careers that serve 
as role models for middle school girls. We're

kind of like a big justice league but our 
superpowers are like coding and curiosity.

The purpose of that is to really 
create a culture shift in how

particularly little girls but 
the world sees women in STEM.
This is Nicole Small,

the CEO of Lyda Hill Philanthropies who 
started the whole if/then initiative.
And really change the perspective and help people

understand that there's so many cool STEM jobs 
right, there's just so many things you can do.

And the benefits of initiatives like if /hen 
are for everyone – to share that you don't

need to look like a crazed genius and work in 
a lab to be a scientist. You can be anyone,

from anywhere ,and work with things 
like power tools, bears, geometry,

soccer teams and rare galaxies. But 
what does this have to do with statues?

I'm guessing you probably haven't thought that 
much about statues. But statues are kind of a

big deal. For thousands of years cultures around 
the world built statues in the names of artistic,

political and historic remembrance. Even if 
you think you're not influenced by statues

these monuments speak volumes 
about the state of society...

just consider the lengths people go to 
to tear them down in the name of protest.

But statues have not celebrated achievements 
equally. A 2016 analysis found that in the 12

largest US cities there were less 
than six statues of real women.

And fictional characters and goddesses like 
Lady Liberty, Alice in Wonderland and this

mother duck don't count as real women. 
As former US treasurer Rosie Rios said:

this is the way we're representing our 
history and we're missing half our population.

Once you hear that statistic you can't unhear 
it, and by the way, once you see these statues

you can't unsee them. And so everywhere we 
were going all of a sudden we were like yeah

there are no statues of women, 
particularly like real women, right?

Broadly this analysis led to a new statue 
initiative, which has seen new statues be

installed, like the first statue of real women 
in central park. But statues don't always have

to be big historic figures or royalty: we can 
celebrate living everyday people who are doing

inspiring work and breaking barriers. As 
Rios said in a recent TEDx talk, we "need

inspirations in order to have aspirations." So for 
Nicole and her group of amazing STEM ambassadors

there was an opportunity to 
do something really cool,

like sharing the inspirational stories of these 
women in STEM. Women like Minerva Cordero,

a professor of mathematics whose 
passion is monumental all on its own.

Mathematics is the queen of all sciences. 
Everything you do has to do with mathematics,

right? And you want to look at statistics, 
you want to look at data encoding information.

Making a movie, you couldn't make a movie if 
some mathematicians had not decided how do

we encrypt this information? Save it so then when 
you project it you get exactly what you recorded?

Side note thank you to all of the 
mathematicians that made this program possible.

Minerva's so passionate that she kept talking 
to passers-by about geometry applications.

i have a new job title for you – after 
all of this as well as being a professor

of mathematics and a statue 
you're a maths cheerleader.

So it comes across absolutely I do love what I 
do, and you know the passion kind of shows right?

So how does a professor became a statue who 
might inspire others to get started in STEM?

Nicole had this idea, really was her idea, 
which was can we make 3D prints? Meet Andy,

who had the job of figuring out how to create 
121 statues. Which involved a lot of questions:

Is it even possible you know 
to do life-size 3D prints?
Were there even printers available?

Is it possible to do 3D scans full 
scale or you know human form? Could

you actually print this many?
Does that technology even exist?

Could you do them in a way that could 
withstand sort of being out in the public?

Producing more than 120 statues is an incredible 
undertaking – I mean a couple of thousand years

ago it took an estimated 700 000 labourers and 
40 years to complete the terracotta warriors!

We probably had like 50 people tell us we 
were crazy. But you know what's really fun?

When people tell you you're crazy and 
you're like it's crazy, but can we do it?

And yeah, they could do it! I mean 
i've already given you a pretty big

spoiler alert. And printing me in 3D 
was quicker than I would have thought.

Generally speaking it's we say 12 to 14 hours, and 
then there's finishing and painting afterwards.

Painting them all bright orange, I'll 
add. But the vibrant colours that kind

of twinkle in the sunlight make them even 
more special to meet and interact with.

My first reaction ID it just brought back so 
many memories of what it took to get to this

point. I was born and raised in Puerto Rico 
and I loved mathematics since a very early

age. And when I was finishing college one of my 
professors said, "hey why don't you get a PhD in

mathematics?" And i'm not sure that's for me. And 
she said, "you should try, go to the United States

and get a PhD." I had to leave Puerto Rico to 
come to the States to get a PhD, which was very

hard because I was very close to my family. But 
I did it! And thanks to her, to my mentor, and

so many people along the way, really help you and 
impact what you do and get you to where you are.

Like Minerva, many of the statues are 
ordinary people who do extraordinary work.
And that was kind of the point.

One of the other main things we did not want to 
do is put you all on pedestals, you know, have you

sort of somehow like a typical iron statue. What 
we wanted to say was no, these women are all

around us, they're all doing amazing things, 
and you just don't know about it, you know?

So of course I had to meet the statues for 
myself... including meeting myself. In the past

i'd only seen a handful of statues displayed 
together, but everything is bigger in Texas.

I'm a bit nervous because I've 
never met myself in 3D before,

but first I have to find 
where I am... so let's go!

How hilarious! It's so weird to think 
is this what I actually look like.

There's some spiders webs on me as well. 
This is a very very strange phenomenon.
I'm quite tall, aren't I?

Yep, it's pretty strange to have a statue 
of yourself. Of course the exhibit is here

to inspire others, but for me it also led to a 
shift in how I viewed myself.., in a good way.

There's a lot of imposter syndrome, this is very 
common with women who work in STEM. I have had

this kind of shift over the past six months where 
i've had this thought like, "am I good enough to

be in this room? Am i doing the right thing? 
Like is this deserved?" You know, all those

kinds of self-doubts that you have go through 
your mind. And i just sit there I'm like, I have

a freaking statue, you know? It's been this kind 
of boost in a way in, in how I view my successes.

Okay so there was still one thing on 
my mind. You know that I like to have

a practical take-home message 
for you guys in these videos.

So for everyone watching at home, what 
do they need to do to become a statue?

That is a great question! You know what, 
find something they're passionate about,

right? Find somebody to look up to, 
like you, and like follow your passion,

right? I hope people go out and inspire to 
change the world because they want to. Getting

to be a statue is like an added bonus these days, 
right, it's like icing on the cupcake right now!

Thinking about following 
your passion is nothing new.

But rethinking who we celebrate in society 
and who gets to be turned into statues

is evidence that sometimes – the most ordinary 
thing you can do can have an extraordinary impact.
Do you mind if I get a selfie?
